title: Digital Competence in the Biological Sciences
text:
This course introduces biology students to digital competence in biological data handling using Excel and R.
The focus is not on programming for its own sake, but on understanding how biological data are: - recorded, - structured, - summarized, - transformed, - interpreted, - and communicated.
Excel and R are used as complementary tools within a broader data lifecycle, from data entry to reproducible analysis.
The course is hands-on, biology-driven, and designed for students with no prior programming experience.

title: Digital Competence in the Biological Sciences
section: How this course fits into Digitale Kompetenzen
text:
How this course fits into Digitale Kompetenzen
This block seminar complements the Digitale Kompetenzen für Studierende der Biowissenschaften lecture series.

The lecture introduces concepts (data, algorithms, modelling, statistics).
This course makes those ideas tangible through practice.

Topics such as inferential statistics, formal modelling, and machine learning are not taught here, but students are conceptually prepared for them.

title: Digital Competence in the Biological Sciences
text:
Teaching philosophy

Tools serve questions, not the other way around
Structure matters more than software
Reproducibility is part of scientific responsibility
Errors are normal and informative
Understanding limits is as important as getting results

Students work in pairs throughout the course, enabling peer learning and collaborative problem solving.

title: Digital Competence in the Biological Sciences
text:
Case study
All exercises are based on a real-world biodiversity monitoring and conservation scenarios from a national protected area in Belize.
Using a single evolving case study allows students to focus on: - reasoning instead of context switching, - continuity across days, - realistic data problems rather than artificial examples.

title: Digital Competence in the Biological Sciences
text:
Course structure
The course runs for 5 days (3 hours each). Each day builds on the previous one and introduces one central idea.


Day 1 – What data is (and what it is not)
Excel as a data entry and structuring tool

Observations, variables, metadata
Data as a simplified representation of reality
Risks of inconsistency and missing context
Excel templates for structured data entry

Key idea
All datasets are already models of reality.



Day 2 – Describing data without overinterpreting it
Excel for descriptive statistics and visualization

Mean, median, variance
Distributions and variability
Visualizations as summaries, not proofs
Honest and misleading plots

Key idea
Descriptive statistics summarize observations, not explanations.



Day 3 – From repetition to algorithms
Why R exists

Repeated tasks and scalability
Algorithms as explicit procedures
Deterministic workflows
Transition from Excel to R

Key idea
Algorithms replace memory and intuition with explicit instructions.



Day 4 – Cleaning data and making work reproducible
R as a data workbench

Data cleaning as scientific work
Data transformation and reshaping
Scripts as documentation
Reproducible workflows

Key idea
If you cannot rerun it, you cannot defend it.



Day 5 – Tools, models, and scientific responsibility
Synthesis and outlook

Models as simplified representations
Tool choice as a scientific decision
Strengths and limits of Excel and R
Mini-project and reflection

Key idea
All models are wrong. Some are useful.

title: Digital Competence in the Biological Sciences
section: What you will be able to do after this course
text:
What you will be able to do after this course
By the end of the course, students will be able to:

Gain an overview of what excel and scripting languages can and can not do
Organize biological data in a structured and transparent way
Use Excel appropriately for data entry and exploration
Use R for basic data cleaning, summaries, and plots
Understand what algorithms and models are at a conceptual level
Judge which tool is appropriate for a given task
Document workflows clearly for reuse and reproducibility

title: Digital Competence in the Biological Sciences
text:
Looking ahead
The skills and concepts introduced here form the foundation for: - statistical inference, - modelling, - bioinformatics, - data-driven biological research. - and real world biological work.
This course is not the end of digital competence training.
It is the starting point.

title: Day 1 – What Data Is (and What It Is Not)
text:
By the end of this day, you should be able to:

explain what biological data represents and what it does not
distinguish data entry, data storage, and data analysis
recognize common sources of data inconsistency
use Excel to enter and structure biological data in a controlled way
understand that every dataset is a simplified representation of reality

No prior experience with Excel or programming is required.

title: Day 1 – What Data Is (and What It Is Not)
text:
Motivation
Biology deals with complex, variable systems.
Data are not reality.
Data are a structured representation of selected aspects of reality.
Before we analyze anything, we must understand: - what was observed, - how it was recorded, - and what information was lost in the process.
Poorly structured data cannot be rescued by sophisticated analysis later.

title: Day 1 – What Data Is (and What It Is Not)
text:
Context: a real-world case study
Throughout this course, we work with a simplified but realistic scenario:

You are working with biodiversity monitoring data from a national protected area in Belize.
Data are collected by rangers, NGOs, and external consultants over long periods of time.

Your task is not to be clever.
Your task is to be reliable.

title: Day 1 – What Data Is (and What It Is Not)
text:
What is data?
In this course, we use the following working definitions:

Observation: one recorded event or measurement
e.g. one species observation at one location and time
Variable: a property that can vary between observations
e.g. species name, location, count, date
Dataset: a collection of observations recorded in a structured form
Metadata: information about how, when, where, and why data were collected

A table is not meaningful by itself.
Meaning comes from structure and context.
crumbs: Course Days
Day 1 – What Data Is (and What It Is Not)

title: Day 1 – What Data Is (and What It Is Not)
text:
Data as a model
Every dataset is already a model:

it includes some aspects of reality
it excludes others
it simplifies complex systems

This idea will return later in statistics and modelling courses.
For now, remember:

Data are never neutral.
Choices are made at the moment of data collection.

title: Day 1 – What Data Is (and What It Is Not)
text:
Excel in the data lifecycle
Excel is widely used in biology because it is:

easy to access
human-readable
flexible

Excel is well suited for: - data entry - inspection - small-scale summaries
Excel is not well suited for: - enforcing consistency - documenting decisions - scaling analyses
Understanding these limits is part of digital competence.
